{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3327768,"name":"","username":"Sidharth_7461","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/848f3c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T14:47:00.265Z","cooked":"

Introducing Wasabi

Sushi Squad is excited to present Wasabi, a dynamic customizable parts tracker built this past offseason for greater organization. Shout out to assembly team members Chen Ting and Ameya, and team captain Aaditya for writing this post.

Why Wasabi?

At Sushi, we iterate fast. Our goal is to design as many iterations as possible, and provide programming/drive with as much time as possible to prepare. This means we focus on optimizing our mechanical and electrical workflows. Wasabi is built on over a year of iteration and optimization of our processes.

Let’s take a look back at the key moments leading to Wasabi.

In the offseason of 2022, we realized the need for a systematic rework of our processes. We created a workflow document outlining each step in our manufacturing process (Sushi Manufacturing Process).

During the use of this document, we noticed a couple issues:

  1. We had zero visibility into parts manufacturing, and we did not keep sufficient track of our BOM (Bill of Materials).
  2. Our BOM was distributed across multiple acquisition channels. Some parts were outsourced to numerous sponsors, while others were machined in house.
  3. We had zero traceability/quality control in our in-house manufacturing. We did not know sufficiently which parts were quality controlled or not.

Thus, we decided to commit to a parts tracking system. Our first parts tracking system consisted of three elements.

  1. Each part received a unique identification code in CAD. The code denoted the version number, subsystem id, and part id.
  2. Each part was entered into a spreadsheet which denoted attributes including the workflow, stock needed, and quantity.
  3. As a part moved through the workflow, its status was updated in the spreadsheet.
  4. Each subsystem had two printed BOMs which we would check off as we kitted, and recheck before assembly.

We used this system in the 2023 offseason, and noticed a significant increase in our manufacturing speed and efficiency. The spreadsheet and our printed BOM system provided unprecedented visibility into our processes, and reduced confusion.

We also acknowledged some gaps in our system:

  1. Data was spread across multiple platforms, leading to confusion in the team.
  2. A spreadsheet worked well for simple workflows like general machining. However, complex workflows like our in house CNC, laser and 3DP, as well as outsourced machining, which required preparation like CAM were not well tracked.
  3. The complexity of the system meant a high overhead by mechanical leadership, meaning that only a few people knew how to use it. This meant that status was not always tracked, leading to uncertainties.

In June of 2023, we started to research other alternative systems. One that stood out to us was the Stoke Fusion platform (https://www.stokefusion.com/). We tried using this software in house but realized that it constrained us to a workflow more complex than we needed. For example, Fusion’s workflows were complex, requiring multiple steps to track a single part. While this works well for an aerospace company like Stoke Space, where traceability is paramount, we decided that this additional complexity would hinder our processes. This was an important learning experience for us as we found out we needed a balance of robustness and simplicity.

In the end, we built Wasabi in August of 2023. Wasabi leverages Notion.so’s powerful database functionality. We were already using Notion as our centralized documentation repository, and it was a natural choice to integrate Wasabi in our existing system.

Since we built Wasabi from scratch, we were able to fine-tune it to fit our needs. This enabled us to give each workflow the amount of complexity it required, rather than use a one-size fits all solution as we had done previously.

We started to use Wasabi in the 2024 build season, and are excited to continue iterating on it in the future.

How Wasabi works

Wasabi is a page on Notion that helps keep Sushi Squad organized in what has been finished and what has not.

In the center of the page is the How to Use; each step for the usage of Wasabi is laid out one by one, making it easy for everyone to use, especially rookies.

On the left side is the Navigation page, bringing us to the subsections of FRC— Design, OMIO, etc. In order to find what is needed, click on the subsection it is in.

Example: Overview; each specific piece has its needed information placed in Part ID, Status, Dimensions, Quantity, Subsystem, Workflow, Stock, Outsourced Material, CAD File, and etc. All the data required is there and when we finish we change the status to “Kitted”, meaning it is complete and has been placed in the Sushi Kit Box (reference photo below).

Limitations

  1. The Part Tracker software is difficult to learn how to use and most rookies struggled to navigate throughout.
  2. IF People don’t follow up after the piece gets manufactured.

Wasabi in action

What we learned this season

Based on Wasabi we learnt how to:

  1. Make more data driven decision making
  2. Optimize resource management
  3. Make more proactive planning
  4. Improve team collaboration
  5. Make more predictive maintenance
  6. Improve budgeting for resources
  7. Transfer parts information faster

Optimizations

  1. Dimensions View
  2. Tapped state
  3. Manufacturing Admin View
  4. 3dp workflow view
  5. Laser View

Try it out!

Try it out at this template. We look forward to seeing how y’all use Wasabi!! We would love to hear feedback on how other teams implement it into their workflows.

Notion seems like a bit of an odd choice, why did you guys settle on that platform over something like Google Sheets? Also from a project management perspective how do you get people to actually utilize the tool? Do you have people report the status to Team leads? Do you have the person who is manufacturing the part put it in the tracking system? What happens if someone doesn’t log the progress of a part into the system?

This seems like a very useful tool that looks like a lot of time was put into it. I am very interested to see if this is something we can implement on my team

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T16:18:17.932Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":105.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457889,"topic_slug":"7461-parts-tracking-system","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61162,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Can you hand me the funny thing (the ziptie gun)?"},"post_url":"/t/7461-parts-tracking-system/457889/2","custom_user_title":"Can you hand me the funny thing (the ziptie gun)?","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327876,"name":"Aaditya ","username":"aadityar","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/48db29/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T17:07:07.409Z","cooked":"

  1. Notion is a platform we are all familiar working with and building on. We run our engineering notebook and operations tasks of notion already, so we use it on a daily basis.

  2. One of our mechanical leads “owns” parts tracker. On major manufacturing days, we have this individual at a separate table, and parts are “checked in” and “checked out” between different steps in the process. During less important manufacturing, the project lead is ultimately in charge of keeping the parts tracker up to date. As part of our daily debrief, we also remind leads to keep the tracker reflective of real world data.

  3. If for some reason there is a gap in tracking (there has been) we are able to fall back on our other systems as described, such as the per-subsystem BOM.
